author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Graphical representation of model performance data is presented in Figure 1B, with the blue curve showing model fitting, blue dots indicating predicted confirmed infections, and red dots representing observed confirmed infections. It is important to note that before February 12, confirmed infections were based solely on nucleic acid diagnosis. From February 12 to 14, both nucleic acid and clinical diagnoses were provided, with only the total confirmed numbers given from February 15 to 21. By comparing three daily data points of nucleic acid diagnosis, we can observe that the fitted model accurately predicts the trend. However, there is a notable disparity between the predicted total infections and confirmed infections in Hubei. The implementation of clinical diagnosis as an additional criterion after February 12 significantly increased confirmation rates, contributing to a surge in confirmed infections. It is crucial to acknowledge that a portion of total infected individuals remains unidentified despite clinical diagnosis. With the inferred parameters, long-term predictions of total infected individuals, unquarantined infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed infections in Hubei are plotted in Figure 1A. The model predicts an end time of 147 days from January 28, 2020, with a total of 62,577 infected individuals. Similar analysis using Stage I data of Hubei, which assumes no strict quarantine or control measures, can provide insight into predicting epidemic trends. The first 10 daily data points from January 20 were utilized to infer parameters. The rest data points were used to test the performance of the model (Fig. 1C, D). As clearly seen in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of CðtÞ and IðtÞ increase dramatically, which are far beyond the observed numbers after Jan 21.
post_context: , and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The significant difference between predictions based on stage I and II data from Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen indicates the effectiveness of preventative measures and quarantines, such as travel restrictions, in controlling the spread of the epidemic. With stricter measures implemented recently to combat COVID-19 in Hubei, we also examined stage III data from Feb 13 onwards. The estimated quarantine rate of 0.6185 in this stage is much higher than the 0.3917 estimated in stage II. The total number of infected individuals is projected to be 49,510, signaling a faster end to the epidemic. Similar analyses were conducted on stage I and II data for Hubei province (excluding Wuhan), the entire country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China. Overall, the model's predictions are highly accurate, showing the importance of quarantine and control measures. Notably, even with stage I data, Beijing's reproductive number is below 1, indicating an early and effective response to COVID-19. Confirmation rates vary between regions, with Hubei having the lowest rate due to a high number of infections overwhelming local resources. This highlights the necessity of prompt responses and efficient control strategies in combating the epidemic.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus has had significant effects on global public health and economies. This study was conducted by researchers from various institutions in Brazil, including the Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional, Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais (IFNMG), Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at the Federal University of Minas Gerais, and the Department of Computer Science at the Federal University of Ouro Preto (UFOP). The research focuses on agent-based simulation and epidemic models, particularly the SEIR model. The article was received on 9 June 2020, revised on 26 June 2020, and accepted on 2 July 2020, before being made available online on 7 July 2020.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, this serves as a valuable tool for policymakers and health authorities to strategize their response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25th, 2020, leading to a significant impact on the country. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil had over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and 55,000 deaths due to COVID-19. Apart from the health crisis, the virus has affected various aspects of life including politics, education, economy, and the environment. Implementing strict social distancing measures is crucial in controlling the outbreak, as indicated by several studies. Many countries are adopting such measures with varying degrees of success, given the complexities of their societies.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Accounting for uncertainties in data is essential in modeling, where each time point's data is considered to follow a probability distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and variance based on the assumed probability distribution. The lack of data is a significant concern for modellers, as it can affect model predictions. Comparing available data (confirmed cases) with model predictions is crucial in understanding the variability in these predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who have been tested and diagnosed with COVID-19, while the infected compartment in transmission models includes all infected individuals, whether symptomatic or not, who may or may not have been confirmed through testing. Model predictions often represent a larger infected population compared to confirmed cases, similar to an iceberg where the tip above the water surface represents the confirmed cases and the submerged portion symbolizes the hidden epidemic of individuals not captured by testing or surveillance. The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirmed cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context: , based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021). Why is this a concern for modellers? When calibrating models, it is crucial to estimate key parameters like the transmission rate b by matching model output with confirmed cases data. To do this accurately, the total number of infectious individuals I(t) must be adjusted by the case-infection ratio r in order to predict confirmed cases effectively. This process helps determine the basic reproduction number R 0, epidemic scale, and peak time. Since the case-infection ratio r for COVID-19 can vary widely, the estimated transmission rate b also has a wide range, leading to diverse model predictions. This variability, known as nonidentifiability, poses a challenge in determining unique model parameters from data during calibration. Different combinations of r and b that fit the data well can result in vastly different predictions. Detecting and addressing nonidentifiability is crucial for improving the reliability of model predictions. The standard nonlinear least squares method may not be effective in addressing this issue due to its reliance on basic optimization algorithms that may not find the best solution among many possible global minima.

author: chunwei

When dealing with a large number of models or non-nested models, different model selection rules apply. For further information on model selection, we recommend referring to recent lecture notes by Portet (2020).3. Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Guangzhou, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Guangzhou, compartment
post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a compartment for latent individuals (E) is included to represent those who are infected but not yet infectious. This latency period is biologically plausible, as COVID-19 has an incubation period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be contagious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of symptoms. While SARS individuals become infectious approximately two days after symptoms appear, evidence suggests that COVID-19 individuals can spread the virus before symptoms start showing. Despite being more biologically realistic, the SEIR model requires two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. The transfer diagrams for both models are depicted in Figure 1, with detailed explanations of model parameters provided in Tables 1 and 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are insignificant during the modeling period of 4 months. By calibrating the models using confirmed case data, the impact of deaths in the R compartment is negligible. The system of differential equations for each model is presented below. Model calibration is based on data reliability and matching them to the rI term in both models, ensuring that deaths in the R compartment do not affect model fitting.

When dealing with a large number of models or models that are not nested, different model selection rules apply. For further information on model selection, we recommend referring to recent lecture notes by Portet (2020).Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, China, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hubei, China, compartment I denotes the infectious population, and R denotes the confirmed cases. In the SEIR model, a latent compartment
post_context: The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body.The distinction between the latent period and incubation period is important. The latent period is the time from infection to becoming infectious, while the incubation period is from infection to the appearance of symptoms like fever and cough for COVID-19. For SARS, individuals become infectious two days after symptoms appear, making the latent period longer than the incubation period. COVID-19 cases have shown individuals can be infectious before symptoms appear, but the length of the latent period is uncertain. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic but has two additional parameters: latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume negligible deaths in certain compartments during model predictions. post_context: . In the SEIR model, a compartment called E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet able to spread the infection. This reflects the biological reality of COVID-19 having a latency period of up to 14 days, during which newly infected individuals may not be contagious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to infectiousness, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the onset of symptoms. Unlike SARS, where individuals become infectious shortly after symptoms begin, evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can spread the virus before showing symptoms. The SEIR model is more biologically accurate than the SIR model, but it requires additional parameters such as the length of the latent period and initial latent population. After the mayor of Hubei Province, China announced at a news conference on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population (N = S + I + R) in Hubei Province, China on January 18 to be 6 million. We utilized the same uniform distributions for the initial parameters in both the SIR and SEIR models, as outlined in Tables 1 and 2. Posterior distributions for all estimated parameters were generated using the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm. The best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were obtained from these posterior distributions, as shown in Table 1 for the SIR model and Table 2 for the SEIR model.

By comparing the calibration results of both the SIR and SEIR models, we calculated their respective corrected Akaike Information Criterion (AICc) as 174 and 186. The difference (D = 186 - 174 = 12) indicates that using the SEIR model may result in a significant loss of information compared to the SIR model. Therefore, further investigation will focus on utilizing the SIR model.

Upon analyzing the calibration results of the SIR model, we observed a linkage between the transmission rate (b) and the diagnosis rate (r). Figure 2 depicts the projection of the unnormalized posterior distribution in the b-r parameter, illustrating the linkage between these two rates.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Data from various sources, such as clinical, surveillance, or administrative, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. This can pose challenges during outbreaks of unknown pathogens occurring in real time, like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. One method to address this challenge is by adopting improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce large confidence or credible intervals. Through our fitting procedure using Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, we were able to achieve this goal.

Our baseline predictions for Hubei, China consist of prediction intervals generated by randomly sampling the posterior distribution. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals. The Bayesian inference utilized newly confirmed cases in Hubei, China from official reports between January 21 and February 4, 2020, during the lockdown and travel restrictions. These projections offer an estimate of the hypothetical epidemic in Hubei, China had further control measures not been implemented after February 7, 2020. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hubei, China together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - April 6.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. Based on our analysis, without the implementation of strict quarantine measures after February 7, the number of peak cases would likely reach around 120,000, and the epidemic in Hubei, China would likely continue until at least May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding varies greatly, with durations generally increasing based on severity. In our model, we account for this by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or die, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability of β. In a well-mixed population where each individual has around 20 contacts per day, a value of β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4–6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2–2.7, depending on factors like population size and age structure. The default value of β = 0.016 in our Covasim model was chosen based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values were chosen as 10:2:2:1 to align with time-use surveys and studies on known contact types. This ratio is also close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In the absence of interventions, transmission events typically occur at a rate of approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can modify the value of β. We account for variations in disease severity, time spent in each state, and individual infectiousness using individual viral load, which follows a two-stage model: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. The default viral load is based on a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and shape parameter of 0.45. This daily viral load impacts the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an agent. Fig 2 shows the viral loads for a representative sample of individuals with default parameter values.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: PLOS COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY presents Covasim, an agent-based model showcasing COVID-19 dynamics and interventions. Variability in the duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding has been noted, with longer durations typically associated with more severe cases. Our model reflects this by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic cases, mild cases, and severe cases, as detailed in Table 1. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases have the possibility of recovery or death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age (Table 2). The transmission of the virus and within-host viral dynamics are modeled such that when a susceptible individual encounters an infectious individual, the virus is transmitted with a certain probability (β). In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day per individual, a β value of 0.016 is equivalent to a doubling time of approximately 4-6 days and an R0 of around 2.2-2.7, with the specific values influenced by factors like population size and age structure. The current default value of β = 0.016 in Covasim was chosen based on calibrations using data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1 chosen for consistency with existing data. In an unmitigated transmission scenario, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can also alter the value of β. Additionally, we account for variations in individual infectiousness through differences in viral load.Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The distribution of transmissions from asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the context, with estimated proportions provided for Seattle [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmission rates are lower when the infected individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that they are not, but we offer a parameter that can be adjusted based on the specific modeling application or context, acknowledging that some studies have suggested significantly lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
